article.title: The mean star formation rates of unobscured QSOs: searching for evidence of suppressed or enhanced star formation

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 1 primarily show about the QSO sample studied in this article?
choices: The distribution of QSO black hole masses as a function of redshift.
The spread of QSO bolometric luminosities and their redshifts.
The mean star formation rate of QSOs in different redshift bins.
The radio luminosity of QSOs as a function of their bolometric luminosity.
The negative correlation between black hole mass and AGN luminosity.
The positive correlation between black hole mass and AGN luminosity.
The constant Eddington ratio across all QSOs in the sample.
The lack of correlation between black hole mass and AGN luminosity.

multiple_choice_question.text: What criteria are used to classify QSOs as radio-luminous in this study?
choices: A simple radio luminosity cut that increases with redshift.
The ratio of radio to optical luminosity (radio loudness).
The excitation level or radiative efficiency of the radio galaxy.
All of the above criteria are used in combination.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the primary reason for using composite SED fitting in this study?
choices: To determine the redshift of the QSOs based on their IR emission.
To measure the star formation rates of QSOs using the 250Âµm band alone.
To disentangle the AGN and star formation contributions to the IR luminosity.
To compare the SEDs of QSOs to those of normal star-forming galaxies.
